prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
The champion of a Chinese chess competition, identified as Yan Chenglong, has lost his title and been prohibited from participating in games for a year following allegations of unacceptable conduct.

The accusations against Yan include cheating by employing a communication device resembling anal beads.

Yan, who is 48 years old, reportedly consumed alcohol with companions in his hotel room shortly after securing the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national event on Hainan Island last week.

The Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) issued a statement revealing that Yan had damaged hotel property and violated public decency and morals by defecating in the bathtub.

Rumors swirled on social media that Yan had cheated using anal beads fitted with wireless transmitters to exchange signals.

However, the CXA expressed doubt that such cheating could be definitively proven based on current information.

Xiangqi has held significant popularity in Asia for centuries.

The CXA did not disclose the exact monetary prize Yan was relinquishing, but Xiangqi tournaments typically award winners with tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.

Yan Chenglong, the victor of a Chinese chess contest, has had his title revoked and is banned from competing for a year due to claims of inappropriate behavior.

Allegations against Yan involve cheating through the use of a communication device, shaped like anal beads.

Yan, aged 48, reportedly consumed alcohol with associates in his hotel room following his achievement of the title "Xiangqi King" at a national event in Hainan Island recently.

There were whispers on social media that Yan had cheated with anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to exchange signs.

Nevertheless, the CXA expressed skepticism that such cheating could be unquestionably verified using the existing information.

The CXA did not reveal the specific monetary reward Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi competitions typically grant winners with tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
